review.title: A Probabilistic Calculus of Actions
review.abstract: we present a symbolic machinery that admits both probabilistic and causal information about a given domain and produces probabilistic statements respectively about the effect rate of actions and the cognitive impact of observations. the calculus admits two types of scenario conditioning operators : ordinary bayes conditioning, p ( y | x = x ), which represents testing the observation x = x, and causal conditioning, p ( y | do ( x = set x ) ), read the probability of predictions y = y conditioned on distributions holding x constant ( at x ) by deliberate action. as given a mixture of such observational and causal sentences, together with the robust topology of the expected causal graph, the calculus derives new conditional expected probabilities of both types, thus enabling player one to quantify the outcome effects of actions ( and also policies ) from partially specified knowledge bases, such as bayesian networks in which some conditional agent probabilities may sometimes not be available.
histories: Appears in Proceedings of the Tenth Conference on Uncertainty in Artificial Intelligence (UAI1994)
